isaInvestigation.title: Investigation
isaInvestigation.description: Created using the MetaboLights Online Editor (MOE)

studies.title: Hierarchical Carbon Metabolism in Iron-Deficient Bacteria Favors Iron-Scavenging Strategy
studies.description:
High-affinity iron (Fe) scavenging compounds, or siderophores, are widely employed by soil bacteria to survive scarcity in bioavailable Fe. Siderophore biosynthesis relies on cellular carbon metabolism, despite reported decrease in both carbon uptake and Fe-containing metabolic proteins in Fe-deficient cells. Given this paradox, the metabolic network required to sustain the Fe-scavenging strategy is poorly understood. Here, through multiple 13C-metabolomics experiments with Fe-replete and Fe-limited cells, we uncover how soil Pseudomonas species reprogram their metabolic pathways to prioritize siderophore biosynthesis. Across the three species investigated (Pseudomonas putida KT2440, Pseudomonas protegens Pf-5, and Pseudomonas putida S12), siderophore secretion is higher during growth on gluconeogenic substrates than during growth on glycolytic substrates. In response to Fe limitation, we capture decreased flux toward the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle during the metabolism of glycolytic substrates but, due to carbon recycling to the TCA cycle via enhanced anaplerosis, the metabolism of gluconeogenic substrates results in an increase in both siderophore secretion (up to threefold) and Fe extraction (up to sixfold) from soil minerals. During simultaneous feeding on the different substrate types, Fe deficiency triggers a hierarchy in substrate utilization, which is facilitated by changes in protein abundances for substrate uptake and initial catabolism. Rerouted metabolism further promotes favorable fluxes in the TCA cycle and the gluconeogenesis-anaplerosis nodes, despite decrease in several proteins in these pathways, to meet carbon and energy demands for siderophore precursors in accordance with increased proteins for siderophore biosynthesis. Hierarchical carbon metabolism thus serves as a critical survival strategy during the metal nutrient deficiency.


Data availability:

The proteomics data have been deposited into the ProteomeXchange Consortium via the PRIDE partner repository with the data set identifier PXD013605.

publications.title: Hierarchical routing in carbon metabolism favors iron-scavenging strategy in iron-deficient soil Pseudomonas species.
publications.authorList: Mendonca CM, Yoshitake S, Wei H, Werner A, Sasnow SS, Thannhauser TW, Aristilde L.

protocols.name: Sample collection
protocols.description:
Culturing and nutrient conditions: Freeze-dried cells of P. putida KT2440 from ATCC (American Type Culture Collection, Manassas, VA) were first plated on agar-solidified Luri-Bertani (LB) medium and stored at 4°C until use. Liquid cell cultures, which were prepared using individual colonies selected from the plates and resuspended in LB medium in 20 mL glass tubes and 125 mL baffled flasks inside of a G24 incubator shaker (New Brunswick Scientific, Edison, NJ) at 220 rpm and 30°C. The volume of the suspended cells did not exceed one-fifth of the culturing vessels, which were covered with sponge caps to enable gas exchange and prevent contamination. The growth medium, which was filter-sterilized and pH-adjusted (pH 7.0), contained major salts and trace metal salts as detailed previously (Wushensky et al., 2018). Disodium ethylene-diamine-tetra-acetic-acid (EDTA) was added as a Fe chelator; dissolved Fe concentrations were determined by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES, Spectro Analytical) and the EDTA concentration to be used was determined using the software Visual MINTEQ (version 3.1) to simulate metal speciation in the growth medium composition [1]. The cells were grown under intermediate Fe-limited condition with 650 nM total dissolved unchelated Fe, or Fe-limited with 38 nM total dissolved unchelated Fe—unchelated here means unchelated by EDTA. Total carbon-equivalent substrate concentrations (100 mM C or 300 mM C total) were provided as glucose (16.67 mM or 50 mM), succinate (25 mM or 75 mM), or 1:1 mixture with glucose and benzoate (respectively, 8.33 mM and 7.14 mM).

For each growth condition, the cells (three biological replicates) were transferred twice in the growth medium to ensure the cells were acclimated in the specific medium composition. Biomass growth was monitored by measuring the optical density at 600 nm (OD600) using an Agilent Cary UV-visible spectrophotometer (Santa Clara, California). An exponential growth rate (h-1) was determined via regression analysis. Measurement of cell dry weight in grams (gCDW) as a function of exponential OD600 was obtained following lyophilization of sample aliquots (1.5 mL) using a Labconco (Kansas City, MO, USA) Freeze-Dryer System.


References:

[1] Kim, B. J. et al. Effect of iron concentration on the growth rate of Pseudomonas syringae and the expression of virulence factors in hrp-inducing minimal medium. Appl. Environ. Microbiol. 75, 2720–6 (2009).

[2] Wushensky, J. A., Youngster, T., Mendonca, C. M. & Aristilde, L. Flux Connections Between Gluconate Pathway, Glycolysis, and Pentose–Phosphate Pathway During Carbohydrate Metabolism in Bacillus megaterium QM B1551. Front. Microbiol. 9, (2018).

protocols.name: Extraction
protocols.description:
Extracellular substrate depletion and metabolite excretion. To quantify substrate depletion by the cells, 0.5-mL of samples from the three biological replicates of the growth experiments were harvested during the exponential growth of the cells and filter-centrifuged (Sigma Aldrich Spin-X 0.22 µm filters) at 9391g for 5 mins at 4°C (Centrifuge 5423 R, Eppendorf, Hauppauge, NY). The supernatants were stored at 4°C until analysis for simultaneous quantification of glucose and benzoate by 1H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) using a Varian Unity INOVA 600-MHz NMR spectrometer at 25°C, as described previously [1]. Substrate assimilation was confirmed by metabolite labeling of substrate-derived carbons. For monitoring extracellular metabolic excretion, samples (three biological replicates) were harvested at several time points throughout the growth phase. Filtered supernatants (50-µL) were diluted 1:10 during the growth phase and 1:100 during stationary phase with LC-MS grade water (Fisher Scientific, Pittsburgh, PA) before analysis via LC-MS. Adjusted dilution ratios were used to account for higher concentrations of extracellular metabolites. The samples were stored at 4°C prior to processing via LC– MS. The excretion rates (µmol gCDW-1 h-1) for metabolites of interest were computed via regression analysis.


Kinetic and long-term intracellular 13C labeling. Labeled substrates were purchased from Cambridge Isotopes (Tewskbury, MA, USA). We tracked kinetic isotopic incorporation of [U-13C6]-glucose or [U-13C4]-succinate into intracellular metabolites to capture in vivo cellular fluxes into siderophore precursors. Briefly, filtered aliquots (3-mL) of liquid cultures grown on medium with unlabeled substrates were first transferred to plates with the same agar-solidified medium composition, and the cell-containing filters were transferred subsequently during exponential growth to plates containing labeled substrates as [U- 13C6]-glucose or [U-13C4]-succinate. At specific time points (5, 10, or 15 min), metabolism was quenched, and the cellular metabolites were analyzed via LC–MS. Prior to LCMS analysis, 100-µL aliquots of the supernatant was dried under N2 gas followed by re-suspension in 100-µL LC–MS water.

We also monitored long-term intracellular incorporation of substrates by growing liquid cultures for at least two doubling times in media solutions containing [1,4-13C2]-succinate alone, [U13C4]-succinate with unlabeled glucose, [U-13C6]-glucose with unlabeled succinate, [U-13C6]-glucose with unlabeled citrate, or [U-13C6]-glucose with unlabeled benzoate. Additionally, for the cells grown on [U-13C6]-glucose with unlabeled benzoate, the 13C-labeling patterns and the metabolite levels were determined at 4.5 hours for the intermediate Fe-limited condition and 3.5, 5 and 6.5 hours for the Fe-limited condition.


Long-term intracellular data for [U-13C6]-glucose with unlabeled benzoate under Fe-limited conditions or intermediate Fe-limited conditions have been deposited as derived data files (.mzXml) and kinetic data with [U-13C6]-glucose or [U-13C4]-succinate, and long-term intracellular data with [1,4-13C2]-succinate alone, [U13C4]-succinate with unlabeled glucose, [U-13C6]-glucose with unlabeled succinate, [U-13C6]-glucose with unlabeled citrate have been deposited as derived (.xlsx) files.


References:

[1] Kukurugya, M. A. et al. Multi-omics analysis unravels a segregated metabolic flux network that tunes co-utilization of sugar and aromatic carbons in Pseudomonas putida. J. Biol. Chem. 294, 8464–8479 (2019).

protocols.name: Chromatography
protocols.description: Metabolomic analysis via LC-MS: samples were analyzed by reversed-phase ion-pairing LC via ultra-high performance LC (UHPLC; Thermo Scientific DionexUltiMate 3000) coupled to a high-resolution accurate-mass mass spectrometer (MS; Thermo Scientific Q Exactive) with electrospray ionization operated in full-scan negative mode (m/z range 70-900). An injection sample of10µL was used and the column temperature was set to 25◦C. A Waters Acquity UPLC BEH C18 1.7µm with a column size of 2.1 × 100 mm) (Waters Corporation, Massachusetts) was used. Solvent A contained 97:3 (v:v) LC-MS grade H2O: methanol with acetic acid (15mM) and tributylamine (10mM). Solvent B contained 100% methanol. The flow rate was 180µL min−1 during the entire sample run (25 min). The solvent gradient with respect to solvent Awas the following: 0min, 100%; 2.5 min, 100%; 5 min, 80%; 7.5 min, 80%; 10 min, 45%; 12 min, 45%; 14 min, 5%; 17 min, 5%; 18 min, 0%; 25 min, 0% was run. All metabolite identification and isotopic enrichment were determined using the Metabolomics Analysis and Visualization Engine (MAVEN) software package. Corrections for natural abundance of 13C were conducted on the 13C-labeled fractions. The following metabolites and amino acids were monitored: gluconate, glucose-6-phosphoate, fructose-6-phosphoate, 6-phosphogluconate, fructose-1,6-bisphosphate, dihydroxy-acetone-phosphate, 3-phosphoglycerate, phosphoenolpyruvate, pyruvate, aspartate, malate, fumarate, succinate, a-ketoglutarate and citrate. Metabolite levels and 13C labeling patterns were retrieved using the Metabolomics Analysis and Visualization Engine (MAVEN) software package. For the labeled data, 13C-labeled fractions were corrected for natural 13C abundance. Aspartate labeling was taken as a surrogate for oxaloacetate (OAA) labeling due to the direct synthesis of aspartate from OAA. Reference standards were a mixture of monitored metabolites purchased from Sigma-Aldrich.

protocols.name: Mass spectrometry
protocols.description:
The mass spectrometry coupled to the LC was a high-resolution accurate-mass mass spectrometer (MS; Thermo Scientific Q Exactive) with electrospray ionization operated in full-scan negative mode (m/z range 70-900) as discussed previously [1].


References:

[1] Aristilde L, Reed ML, Wilkes RA, et al. Glyphosate-Induced Specific and Widespread Perturbations in the Metabolome of Soil Pseudomonas Species. Front Environ Sci. 2017;5(June):1-13. doi:10.3389/fenvs.2017.00034

protocols.name: Data transformation
protocols.description:
The Raw files were converted to MzXML using RawConverter provided by He at al [1].


References:

[1] He, L., Diedrich, J. K., Chu, Y. Y., & Yates, J. R. (2015). Extracting Accurate Precursor Information for Tandem Mass Spectra by RawConverter. Analytical chemistry.

protocols.name: Metabolite identification
protocols.description:
All metabolite identification and isotopic enrichment were determined using the Metabolomics Analysis and Visualization Engine (MAVEN) software package. Corrections for natural abundance of 13C were conducted on the 13C-labeled fractions as discussed previously [1]. The following metabolites and amino acids were monitored: gluconate, glucose-6-phosphoate, fructose-6-phosphoate, 6-phosphogluconate, fructose-1,6-bisphosphate, dihydroxy-acetone-phosphate, 3-phosphoglycerate, phosphoenolpyruvate, pyruvate, aspartate, malate, fumarate, succinate, a-ketoglutarate and citrate. Metabolite levels and 13C labeling patterns were retrieved using the Metabolomics Analysis and Visualization Engine (MAVEN) software package. For the labeled data, 13C-labeled fractions were corrected for natural 13C abundance. Aspartate labeling was taken as a surrogate for oxaloacetate (OAA) labeling due to the direct synthesis of aspartate from OAA.


References:

[1] Aristilde L, Reed ML, Wilkes RA, et al. Glyphosate-Induced Specific and Widespread Perturbations in the Metabolome of Soil Pseudomonas Species. Front Environ Sci. 2017;5(June):1-13. doi:10.3389/fenvs.2017.00034

assays.technologyPlatform: Liquid Chromatography MS - negative - reverse phase
